Perhaps I should say at the outset that I do not agree with most of
these criticisms of America and of our foreign policy. I think many —
perhaps most — of them are based on misunderstanding which might be
cleared up with greater effort on both sides.
Hor do I believe that this misunderstanding is due to any failure of
American information agencies to carry out their difficult Jobs in this
country, though we have few reliable methods of measuring the effective¬
ness of such efforts.
But I do think that what these Italians are thinking and saying about
us is important. Whether their beliefs are right or wrong, they are
sincerely held; they constitute a current political fact of life in Italy,
and perhaps in western Europe. We must take these beliefs into account;
to ignore them would be foolhardy indeed.
What are the things about America that bother these Italian friends?
First of all they generally cite what they regard as our intransi-
geanoe; our unwillingness to negotiate; the inflexibility of our foreign
policies.
